questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement regarding the marked structure in the given image of the head.

choices.text: It arises from the posteromedial aspect of the external carotid artery.
It contributes to the supply of the nasal septum.
It give off branches in the cervical region.

questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given image, emerging on the edge of the mandible at the anteroinferior border of the masseter muscle is the facial artery. 

The facial artery is an anterior branch (option A) of the external carotid artery, given off in the neck region, just above the greater cornua of the hyoid bone. The artery is very sinuous throughout its course. This is so that the artery is able to adapt to the movements of the neck and the face during daily activities. It gives of four branches in the neck and four on the face.

Its 4 branches in the neck region are (option D):

  • Ascending palatine artery supplies the soft palate and the eustachain tube. 
  • Tonsillar artery is the main arterial supply to the palatine tonsils (option B)
  • Submental artery is the largest cervical branch of facial artery. It supplies the overlying skin and muscles in the submental region. 
  • Glandular branches supply the submandibular salivary gland. 

Its 4 named branches on the face are:

  • Premasseteric artery is small and inconstant. When present, it goes upwards along the anterior border of masseter and supplies the surrounding area.
  • Inferior labial artery arises near the angle of the mouth. It runs between the orbicularis oris muscle and the mucous membrane. It supplies the glands, mucous membrane and the muscles.
  • Superior labial artery is larger and more tortuous than the inferior labial artery. It pursues a similar course along the superior labial margin, between the mucous membrane and orbicularis oris, anastomoses with its contralateral fellow, and supplies the upper lip. It gives off a septal branch that ramifies anteroinferiorly in the nasal septum. (option C)
  • Lateral nasal artery is given off by the side of the nose, supplies the dorsum and ala of the nose, and anastomoses with its contralateral fellow. 

The part of the artery distal to its terminal branch is called the angular artery.

questions.text: All of the following pass deep to the marked structure, except?

choices.text: Palmar cutaneous branch of median nerve

questions.solution:
The marked structure is the flexor retinaculum of the wrist. It can be identified by the palmaris longus tendon passing superficial to it and becoming the palmar aponeurosis. Palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve passes superficial to the flexor retinaculum. 

Structures lying superficial to flexor retinaculum are:

  • Palmaris longus tendon
  • Palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve
  • Palmar cutaneous branch of the ulnar nerve
  • Ulnar nerve
  • Ulnar vessels

The structures lying deep to flexor retinaculum are:

  • Lateral compartment:
    • Flexor carpi radialis
  • Medial compartment:
    • Median nerve
    • Flexor pollicis longus
    • 4 tendons each of flexor digitorum superficialis and flexor digitorum profundus

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given image.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given image of transverse section of basal ganglia is a gray matter structure known as claustrum. It is flanked by external capsule medially and extreme capsule and insular cortex laterally. 

The gray matter structures which can be seen on a transverse section of the cerebrum are:

  • Head of caudate nucleus forms the lateral wall of the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle.
  • Thalamus contributes to the floor of the body of the lateral ventricle.
  • Lentiform nucleus is a wedge-shaped mass related medially to the internal capsule, which separates it from the caudate nucleus and the thalamus and laterally to the external capsule. A vertical plate of white matter divides the lentiform nucleus into globus pallidus medially and putamen laterally. 
  • Claustrum separates the external capsule from the extreme capsule and the subcortical white matter of the insular cortex. The function of claustrum is not known.

All the capsules (internal capsule, external capsule and extreme capsule) are white matter bundles while all the nuclei (caudate nucleus, lentiform nucleus, thalamus) are masses of gray matter.

questions.text: While dissecting the inguinal canal, the following structure is noted. Which of the following does not contribute to the coverings of the structure marked as 'A'?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as 'A' is the spermatic cord. External oblique aponeurosis, internal oblique, and transversalis fascia contribute to the three coverings of the spermatic cord. There is no contribution from the transversus abdominis muscle. 

The coverings of the spermatic cord are:

  1. External spermatic fascia is a continuation of the external oblique aponeurosis and is attached to the superficial inguinal ring. 
  2. Cremasteric fascia and cremasteric muscle are derived from the internal oblique muscle and form the middle covering of the spermatic cord. They are involved in the cremasteric reflex. Gently touching the skin around the anterior aspect of the thigh stimulates the ilioinguinal nerve (afferent). The sensory fibres enter the spinal cord at the L1 level. The efferent nerve is the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve (L1, L2), which causes contraction of the cremasteric muscle and the elevation of the testis. The cremasteric reflex is more active in children and diminishes with age. 
  3. Internal spermatic fascia is derived from transversalis fascia and is attached to the deep inguinal ring. 

Related Pearl: Inguinal canal and spermatic cord contents

Inguinal canal contents:

Male Female
  • Spermatic cord  (with genital branch of genitofemoral nerve)
  • Ilioinguinal nerve
  • Round ligament of the uterus 
  • Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve
  • Ilioinguinal nerve

Spermatic cord contents:

  • Three arteries:
    • Testicular artery
    • Deferential artery
    • Cremasteric artery
  • Two nerves:
    • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
    • Sympathetic nerve fibers
  • Three other structures:
    • Ductus deferens
    • Pampiniform plexus of veins
    • Lymphatic vessels

questions.text: Which of the following veins accompanies the structure marked in the given image?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given image is the left anterior descending artery located in the anterior interventricular groove. The vein which accompanies this artery is the great cardiac vein. 

The great cardiac vein begins at the apex of the heart. It ascends in the anterior interventricular sulcus. At the coronary sulcus, the great cardiac vein turns to the left and lies at the base of the heart. Here, it is associated with the circumflex branch of the left coronary artery. In the coronary sulcus, the great cardiac vein enlarges to form the coronary sinus, which drains into the right atrium. 

 

Middle cardiac vein begins near the apex of the heart and ascends in the posterior interventricular sulcus. It is associated with the posterior interventricular branch of the right or the left coronary artery. Small cardiac vein begins in the anterior section of the coronary sulcus between the right atrium and the right ventricle. It continues in this groove onto the base of the heart and then enters the coronary sinus. It accompanies the right coronary artery in its course and may receive the right marginal vein. Posterior cardiac vein lies on the posterior surface of the left ventricle just to the left of the middle cardiac vein. 

Anterior veins of the right ventricle drain the anterior portion of the right ventricle and enter the right atrium directly. Venae cordis minimae or veins of Thebasius drain directly into the cardiac chambers and are mainly associated with right atrium and right ventricle. 

Related Pearl: Structures passing through heart sulci

questions.text: The following image depicts the dissection of the forearm. Identify structure marked by the red arrow.
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the pronator quadratus muscle.

Pronator quadratus is a flat quadrilateral shaped muscle, that extends across the front of the distal ends of the radius and ulna. The muscle is supplied by the anterior interosseus artery and causes the pronation of the forearm.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles will be paralyzed if there is an injury to the nucleus underlying the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The image shows the floor of the fourth ventricle, and the facial colliculus is marked. The abducens nucleus lies underneath the facial colliculus. Injury to the abducens nucleus will lead to paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle. 

The facial colliculus is present on the floor of the fourth ventricle at the level of the lower pontine tegmentum. This colliculus contains the abducens nerve nucleus and the fibers of the facial nerve, which form the internal genu as they travel around the abducens nerve nucleus. The abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) then emerges from the brainstem between the pons and the medulla and runs through Dorello's canal. The abducens nerve enters the superior orbital fissure via the cavernous sinus and innervates the lateral rectus muscle.

Structures on the floor of the 4th ventricle (Rhomboid Fossa)

Ridges:

  • Transverse fibers: Striae medullares
  • Striae medullaris divides rhomboid fossa into 2 parts: Rostral pontine and Caudal medullary

Medial to lateral in rostral pontine part:

  • Midline longitudinal sulcus: Median sulcus
  • Bilateral eminences: Medial eminence
  • Bilateral longitudinal sulcus: Sulcus limitans
  • Bilateral areas: Vestibular area (deeper to it is the vestibular nucleus)

Upper and lower ends of sulcus:

  • Bluish-colored, uppermost area where sulcus limitans ends: Locus coeruleus
  • Depression, the upper area of sulcus limitans: Superior fovea
  • Depression, the lower area of sulcus limitans: Inferior fovea

Cranial nerve nucleus elevations:

  • Elevation on the medial eminence: Facial colliculus
  • Elevations in the lowermost area in the shape of 2 triangles: Hypoglossal and vagal triangles

Circumventricular organ:

  • Between the vagal triangle and gracile tubercle below: Area postrema

Other Options:

Option A: The genioglossus muscle is innervated by the hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII) arising from the hypoglossal nucleus in the medulla.

Option B: The orbicularis oculi muscle is responsible for closing the eyelids and is innervated by the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). 

Option D: The cricothyroid muscle is responsible for tensing the vocal cords and is innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X).

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given image and choose the incorrect statement about it.

choices.text: It is the nerve of the sixth pharyngeal arch
Loops around the subclavian artery on the right side
Gives sensory supply to the larynx above the vocal folds

questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above image is the recurrent laryngeal nerve. The recurrent laryngeal nerve gives the sensory supply to the larynx below the vocal folds.

The left and right recurrent laryngeal nerves arise from the respective side vagus nerves. The left recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the arch of aorta, while the right recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the right subclavian artery. Both of them ascend in the groove between the trachea and the esophagus and enter the larynx deep to the margin of the inferior constrictor muscle. They may pass medial to, lateral to, or through the lateral ligament of the thyroid gland, which attaches the thyroid gland to the trachea and lower part of the cricoid cartilage on each side. This relationship is important during surgery of the thyroid gland. 

The recurrent laryngeal nerves give sensory supply to the larynx below the level of the vocal cord and motor supply to all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid. In addition, the cricopharyngeus part of the inferior constrictor muscle is also supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve.  

Related Pearl: Nerves of Larynx

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding the marked structure in the given image.

choices.text: Originates from the the tendon of flexor digitorum profundus

questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given image is the first lumbrical and it arises from the tendon of flexor digitorum profundus.

There are four lumbrical muscles. They originate from the tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus (option B). They then pass to the radial side of the corresponding fingers and are inserted into the dorsal digital expansion of the extensor digitorum. While the first and second lumbricals are unipennate in nature(Option D), the third and the fourth are bipennate.

The median nerve innervates the first and second lumbricals. The deep terminal branch of the ulnar nerve innervates the third and the fourth (option C). The action of lumbricals is flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joint and extension of interphalangeal joints (option A).

questions.text: Which nerve gives motor supply to the marked muscle of the gluteal region?
questions.solution:
The marked muscle in the given image is gemellus inferior. It is innervated by nerve to quadratus femoris. 

Both the gemelli don't have their own specific nerve supply. While gemellus inferior is given motor supply by nerve to quadratus femoris, gemellus superior is innervated by nerve to obturator internus. 

Branches from S1 and S2 innervate the piriformis muscle.

Related Pearl: Various muscles of the gluteal region and their innervation

Muscles

Innervation

Gluteus maximus

 Inferior gluteal nerve

Gluteus medius and minimus

 Superior gluteal nerve

Pyriformis

 Nerve to pyriformis

Obturator internus, Gemellus superior

 Nerve to obturator internus

Quadratus femoris, Gemellus inferior

 Nerve to quadratus femoris

Related Pearl: Gluteal Muscles

 
Gluteus Medius
Origin- Outer surface of ilium between anterior and posterior gluteal lines.
Insertion -Oblique ridge on the lateral surface of the greater trochanter.
Gluteus Minimus
Origin- Outer surface of ilium between anterior and inferior gluteal lines
Insertion -Ridge on the anterior surface of greater trochanter
Gluteus Maximus

Origin - Posterior aspect of dorsal ilium posterior to posterior gluteal line, posterior superior iliac crest, posterior inferior aspect of sacrum and coccyx, and sacrotuberous ligament

Insertion - Primarily in fascia lata at the iliotibial band; also into the gluteal tuberosity on posterior femoral surface

Related Pearl: Structures Passing Through the Sciatic Foramens

Structures passing through the greater sciatic foramen

The piriformis is the key muscle of this region. It emerges from the pelvis, and fills the foramen almost completely.

Structures passing above the piriformis

  • Superior gluteal nerve
  • Superior gluteal vessels

Structures passing below the piriformis

  • Inferior gluteal nerve         
  • Inferior gluteal vessels
  • Sciatic nerve                                              
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh
  • Nerve to quadratus femoris                  
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels                                  
  • Nerve to obturator internus

Note: The last three structures, after a short course in the gluteal region, enter the lesser sciatic foramen, where the pudendal nerve and internal pudendal vessels run in the pudendal canal.

Structures passing through the lesser sciatic foramen

  • Tendon of obturator internus
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels
  • Nerve to obturator internus

questions.text: Which of the following gives rise to the structure marked in the given image of the liver?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the falciform ligament of the liver. It is an embryological derivative of ventral mesentery, which itself arises from septum transversum. 

Septum transversum is the undifferentiated lateral plate mesoderm at the cranial end of the embryo. It gives rise to:

  • Central tendon of diaphragm
  • Fibrous pericardium
  • Liver stroma
  • Ventral mesogastrium

As the liver grows into the mesenchyme of the septum transversum, ventral mesentery is divided into two parts:

  1. Lesser omentum, which extends from the lower portion of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper portion of the duodenum to the liver (hepato-gastric and hepato-duodenal ligaments)
  2. Ligaments of the liver: all ligaments of the liver except ligamentum teres are derived from the ventral mesentery. This includes falciform ligament, right and left triangular ligaments, and coronary ligaments. 

Dorsal mesentery connects the abdominal organs to the posterior abdominal wall. It runs from the lower end of the esophagus to the cloacal region of the hindgut. Depending on the abdominal organ to which it is attached, it has multiple regions: dorsal mesogastrium, mesoduodenum, mesentery proper (to the small intestine), mesocolon, mesoappendix, mesosigmoid, and mesorectum. The dorsal mesogastrium gives rise to greater omentum, gastrosplenic ligament, lienorenal ligament, and gastrophrenic ligament.

questions.text: What is the action of the marked structure?

choices.text: Dorsiflexion and eversion of the foot
Dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot

questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given image is the tibialis anterior muscle. Its action is dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot.

Tibialis anterior can be identified as the most medial muscle of the anterior compartment of the leg. The order of the muscles in the anterior compartment of the leg is (medial to lateral): tibialis anterior, extensor hallucis longus, extensor digitorum longus and peroneus tertius. Tibialis anterior muscle is medial to extensor digitorum longus and is inserting towards the medial side of the foot and can be identified in the specimen.

Tibialis anterior muscle originates from lateral condyle and lateral surface of the tibial shaft and the adjacent interosseus membrane. It is inserted into the medial and inferior surface of the medial cuneiform and the adjoining part of the base of the first metatarsal. It receives its innervation from the deep peroneal nerve (L4 and L5). Its actions include dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot. This muscle is most active during activities in which both of these movements are combined, such as walking. 

 

 

Other options:

Option A: Plantar flexion of the foot is a function of the muscles of the posterior compartment of the leg. 

Option B: Dorsiflexion and eversion of the foot is a function of the peroneus tertius muscle. 

Option C: Extension of the great toe is a function of the extensor hallucis longus muscle. 

Related Pearl: Various muscles of the leg and their innervation:

 

Muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg and dorsum of foot

Nerve Supply

Tibialis anterior

 

 

Deep Peroneal Nerve

Extensor hallucis longus

Extensor digitorum longus

Peroneus tertius

Extensor digitorum brevis

Muscles of the lateral component of the leg

 

Peroneus longus

 

Superficial Peroneal Nerve

Peroneus brevis

Superficial muscles of the posterior compartment of the leg

 

Gastrocnemius

 

Tibial Nerve

Soleus

Plantaris

Deep muscles of the posterior compartment of the leg

 

Popliteus

 

 

Tibial Nerve

Flexor digitorum longus

Flexor hallucis longus

Tibialis posterior

questions.text: Which of the following is not a content of the highlighted triangle?
questions.solution:
The highlighted triangle is the supraclavicular (subclavian/omoclavicular/ Ho's triangle) triangle. The spinal accessory nerve is not the content of this triangle.

The supraclavicular triangle is the lower and smaller division of the posterior triangle of the neck.

Boundaries :

  • Superior - inferior belly of the omohyoid muscle
  • Inferior - clavicle
  • Anterior - posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle
  • Posterior - anterior border of the trapezius

Contents:

  • Nerves - trunks of the brachial plexus, nerve to serratus anterior (long thoracic nerve of bell), suprascapular nerve, nerve to subclavius.
  • Vessels - the third part of the subclavian artery and vein, suprascapular artery and vein, the origin of the transverse cervical artery, lower part of the external jugular vein
  • Lymph nodes

Related Pearl: Triangles of the Neck

questions.text: Identify the marked structure.
questions.solution:
The marked structure is arising on the anterior surface of the midbrain and traversing between the posterior cerebral artery and the superior cerebellar artery, so it is likely to be oculomotor nerve. 

Oculomotor nerve is a purely motor nerve arising from two nuclei: main motor nucleus and the accessory parasympathetic nucleus. The main nucleus lies at the level of the superior colliculus of the midbrain. The accessory parasympathetic nucleus (Edinger-Westphal nucleus) is situated posterior to the main nucleus. 

The oculomotor nerve emerges on the anterior surface of the midbrain in the interpeduncular fossa. lt then passes between the posterior cerebral and the superior cerebellar arteries. It further continues into the middle cranial fossa in the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus. Here, it divides into a superior and an inferior ramus, and then enters the orbital cavity through the superior orbital fissure.

The oculomotor nerve supplies the following muscles of the eye:

  1. Levator palpebrae superioris
  2. Superior rectus
  3. Medial rectus
  4. Inferior rectus
  5. Inferior oblique
  6. Parasympathetic fibers to the constrictor pupillae of the iris and ciliary muscles

Related Pearl: Origins of cranial nerves at the base of the brain

Cranial nerve origins as seen in gross anatomy:

  • III cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus.  
  • IV cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of inferior colliculus - the only nerve the exits from the dorsal aspect
  • V cranial nerve: The substance of pons 
  • VI, VII, and VIII cranial nerves:  Pontomedullary junction
  • IX, X, and XI cranial nerves(nucleus ambiguus): Posterolateral sulcus   
  • XII cranial nerve: Anterolateral sulcus (between pyramid and olive)

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not supplied by the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The given image is of the femoral triangle and the marked structure, which lies lateral to the femoral vessels, is the femoral nerve. The iliacus, pectineus, and vastus medialis are all supplied by the femoral nerve. However, the psoas major muscle is supplied by branches from the anterior rami of L1 to L3. 

The femoral nerve is formed from the dorsal division of L2-L4 from the lumbar plexus. It enters the femoral triangle by passing under the inguinal ligament. In the femoral triangle, it lies lateral to the femoral artery and outside the femoral sheath. Before entering the thigh, the femoral nerve gives branches to the iliacus and pectineus muscles. After passing under the inguinal ligament, the femoral nerve divides into anterior and posterior branches.

Anterior branch gives:

  • Motor supply to sartorius
  • Medial cutaneous nerve of thigh
  • Intermediate cutaneous nerve of thigh

Posterior branch gives:

  • Motor supply to rectus femoris
  • Motor supply to the three vastii (vastus lateralis, vastus intermedius, and vastus medialis)
  • Saphenous nerve, which supplies the skin on the medial side of the leg and the foot

Related Pearl: Femoral Triangle

The femoral triangle is a depressed, intermuscular space present in the anteromedial aspect of the proximal thigh.

Boundaries of Femoral triangle are:

Medially- Medial border of Adductor longus

Laterally- Medial border of Sartorius

Base- Inguinal ligament

Floor (lateral to medial)- Iliacus, Psoas major, Pectineus, Adductor longus

Roof- Skin, Superficial fascia, Fascia lata, superficial branches of femoral vessels–superficial epigastric, superficial external pudendal, superficial circumflex iliac vessels and GSV. 

Note: Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve which forms a content of the triangle also forms its roof as it pierces the fascia to supply the skin over the triangle. 

Contents:

  • Femoral sheath containing lymph node of Cloquet, femoral vein, femoral artery, femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve.
  • Femoral nerve and its branches
  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of thigh

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the action of the marked muscle?

choices.text: Elevation and retraction of the mandible
Depression and protraction of the mandible

questions.solution:
The marked muscle which is inserting on the coronoid process and anterior ramus of the mandible is the temporalis muscle. Its action is to elevate and retract the mandible. 

Temporalis muscle originates from the bone of the temporal fossa and the temporal fascia and goes on to attach on the coronoid process and anterior ramus of the mandible. It is innervated by deep temporal nerves which originate from the anterior trunk of the mandibular nerve. Temporalis muscle elevates the mandible and so closes the mouth. The posterior fibers of the muscle retract the mandible after it has been protruded. These muscle fibers of temporalis are almost horizontal and are the only source of mandibular retraction. 

Related Pearl: Muscles of mastication

Muscles Origin Insertion Action
Lateral pterygoid

Upper head - Infratemporal surface, sphenoid bone

Lower head - Lateral pterygoid plate

Upper head - Pterygoid fovea 

Lower head - TMJ capsule and articular disc

Depresses mandible (with suprahyoid muscles)

Jaw protrusion

Grinding(Side to side) movements
Medial pterygoid

Superficial head - Maxilla

Deep head - Lateral pterygoid plate, Palatine bone

Angle of mandible

Ramus of mandible behind mandibular foramen

Elevates mandible  

Jaw protrusion

Grinding(side to side) movements
Temporalis

Temporal fossa

Temporal fascia

Ramus of mandible

Coronoid process

Elevates mandible

Side-to-side movements

Jaw retraction
Masseter Zygomatic arch Ramus of mandible

Elevates mandible

Jaw protrusion

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the structure marked in the given image?

choices.text: Formed by retromandibular vein and facial vein
Great auricular nerve runs with it
Pierces the deep cervical fascia in the carotid triangle

questions.solution:
The marked structure in the given image is the external jugular vein. It runs with the great auricular nerve, lying posterior to its upper half. 

The formative tributaries of the external jugular vein are the posterior auricular vein and the posterior division of the retromandibular vein (option A). It descends from the angle of the mandible to the midpoint of the clavicle, running obliquely and superficial to the sternocleidomastoid muscle. It is covered by skin, superficial fascia, and platysma, and is separated from the sternocleidomastoid by the deep cervical fascia. At the root of the neck in the posterior triangle (option D), it pierces the deep cervical fascia and ends in the subclavian vein (option C).  The vein crosses the transverse cutaneous nerve and lies parallel with the great auricular nerve, posterior to its upper half.

questions.text: Which of the following connects the structures marked as 'A' and 'B'?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as 'A' in the given image is lateral ventricle, and 'B' is third ventricle. The structure connecting these two is foramen of Monro.

The ventricular system is derived from the inner lumen of the developing neural tube. Lining the ventricles is the choroid plexus, consisting of modified ependymal cells responsible for producing the CSF. From the lateral ventricles, CSF flows through the interventricular foramen of Monro to the third ventricle. The third ventricle communicates with the fourth ventricle via the cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius (option A), which courses through the midbrain. Surrounded by the pons and medulla anteriorly and the cerebellum posteriorly, the fourth ventricle sends CSF out of the ventricular system and into the subarachnoid space via the lateral foramina of Luschka (option C) and midline foramen of Magendie (option D). 

Related Pearl: Boundaries of the 3rd ventricle

Roof: Choroid plexus

Lateral wall:

  • Thalamus
  • Hypothalamus

Anterior wall: 

  • Anterior commissure
  • Lamina terminalis

Posterior wall: 

  • Pineal gland
  • Posterior commissure
  • Aqueduct of Sylvius

Floor: 

  • Optic chiasma
  • Infundibulum
  • Mamillary bodies
  • Posterior perforating substance
  • Tegmentum of midbrain

questions.text: Identify the marked structure.
questions.solution:
In the given coronal section of the brain, the marked structure is fornix.

The fornix is a part of the connecting pathways of the limbic system. It arises from the hippocampus which wraps around the thalamus and ends in the mammillary body. It connects the hippocampus with distal brain sites. The fornix has two types of fibres:

  • Association fibres: They connect the various cortical regions within the same hemisphere 
  • Commissural fibres: They connect the corresponding regions of two hemispheres. It is seen in the hippocampal commissure of the fornix. 

It is supplied by the anterior communicating artery arising from the anterior cerebral artery.

questions.text: Which of the following have no contribution in the embryological development of the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the given image is the inferior vena cava (IVC). 

The inferior vena cava is a composite vessel that develops from the remodeling of successive venous complexes. The veins contributing to the formation of IVC from below upwards are as follows:

  1. Common iliac veins
  2. Right posterior cardinal vein
  3. Postcardinal-supracardinal anastomosis
  4. Right supracardinal vein
  5. Supracardinal-subcardinal anastomosis
  6. Right subcardinal vein
  7. Cardiac termination of the right vitelline hepatocardiac vein (right hepatocardiac vein)

The right umbilical vein atrophies during development. The left umbilical vein joins the right vitelline vein and their common termination is known as the right hepatocardiac vein, which forms the terminal part of the IVC.
